abstract.p: The dynamics of the compliant legged robots are commonly characterized by the spring loaded inverted pendulum model. In this article, a new model is presented for the impact of the compliant legged robots. Compared with the spring loaded inverted pendulum model, the new model provides a means to take into account the factors such as the sliding of the terminal, the vibrations of the leg with distributed compliance and variation of the nonlinear contact force. The effectiveness of the model is validated by the finite element program LS-DYNA from the velocity and energy point of view. Based on the method used, the influences of the parameters, such as the incident angle, width, thickness and Young’s modulus of the flexible leg on the dynamic characteristics of the robot, are analysed. It is found that the post-impact vertical velocity of the robot decreases with the increasing incident angles, and increases approximately linearly with the width and thickness, while the variation of Young’s modulus of the flexible leg has little effects on it. The same is true of the energy loss ratio during the impact. All the parameters investigated are more intuitive than the stiffness described in the spring loaded inverted pendulum model and can be utilized directly for the optimization design and locomotion control of the compliant legged robots. In addition, the vibrations and multiple impacts can be predicted by the proposed model to reduce the energy loss.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Much recent interest in the field of dynamic legged locomotion has been placed on compliant legged robots. These robots always take principles from running animals that make use of the elastic function of the muscles, tendons and ligaments distributed in their bodies and limbs to return energy. Compliant legged robots have several advantages over the traditional rigid legged ones: higher speed, higher energy efficiency, lighter weight, stronger obstacle-surmounting ability and shock resistance.1–3

The compliant elements are implemented in the leg mechanisms to improve the speed and energy efficiency of the running robots. For instance, Brown and Zeglin4 made use of fibreglass as highly resilient leg that resembles an archer’s bow, and the preliminary experiments demonstrated that as much as 70% of the energy can be recovered from one hop to the next. The biologically inspired RHex (hexapod robot) can produce energetic running gaits and run as fast as 2.7 m/s (about five body-lengths), attributing to its legs designed from compliant materials.3 Additionally, the six-legged robot could navigate over highly broken and unstable, natural terrain due to its special leg design.5 iSprawl (independent version of the Sprawl robots) is a cockroach-inspired hexapod with compliant, under-actuated legs and runs at 15 body-lengths/s.6 More recently, flexure joints were introduced into the leg design of DASH2 (dynamic autonomous sprawled hexapod), a lightweight and fast-running robot which can survive high falls without damage. Thus, it can be seen that the light, compliant mechanisms are adopted widely in leg design with various forms. However, how to design the shape and parameters of the cross section of the leg to achieve optimal running performance is still an open question.

To the best of our knowledge, a number of researchers in biomechanics and robotics focus on the spring loaded inverted pendulum (SLIP) model,7,8 because the model provides a reasonable approximation to the centre of mass (COM) motion of a running animal or a successful running robot such as RHex, DASH and iSprawl.2,9,10 Furthermore, the relationship between the stiffness of the massless leg spring and forward running speed of the animal was presented by McMahon and Cheng,11 Seyfarth et al.12 under the assumption that the system bounces passively without viscous loss. In other words, tuned leg stiffness is important for passive dynamic stability as well as energy efficiency of legged locomotion, especially when the environmental conditions change or the gait requires to be adjusted. This principle is also exhibited by a series of most current running robots such as AMASC8 (actuator with mechanically adjustable series compliance) or EDUBOT5 (hexapod robot adapted for education). However, the friction between moving parts and aerodynamic drag does exist objectively. More importantly, a considerable part of energy will be lost when the terminal of the leg slides on the ground and vibrates during impact. Accordingly, it is impossible for the robots to move in a completely passive pattern without supplying energy to the system. In addition, the stiffness is not an intuitive parameter, and it depends on the shape, materials and the cross section of the leg; hence, it cannot be used by the designer directly.

A few researchers also studied the SLIP model by considering compliance in series with the hip joint, which is used to generate the fore–aft oscillations of the legs to avoid large energy expenditure.13,14 The SLIP models, whether with hip compliance or not, make sense in predicting the dynamic characteristics of the compliant legged robots with centralized compliance, such as leg spring or hip spring. Nevertheless, when the compliant mechanisms are introduced into the legs, the properties of the distributed multi-directional compliance cannot be captured by the SLIP models.

Furthermore, the ground reaction force during the impact is assumed to be proportional to the deflection of the leg springs in previous studies.7,11,14 But in fact, the contact force is determined by the deformation of the contact area. Meanwhile, the magnitude of the contact force has significant effect on the dynamic behaviours of the robots.

The objective of this article is to establish a model that can be used to predict the motion of the compliant legged robot after the impact and evaluate the energy loss during the impact. By utilizing a finite number of vibrational modes, the distributed compliance and vibrations of the leg are taken into account. Meanwhile, the nonlinear contact force is calculated according to Hertz theory and Coulomb’s law. Based on this, an analytical continuous dynamic model is then developed for the impact of the compliant legged robots represented by a multi-body system composed of a rigid body, a compliant leg and compliant support surface. The impact equations of the robot are derived by Lagrange’s formalism, and the post-impact behaviour of the robot is solved numerically. Furthermore, the influence of the incident angles, width, thickness and materials of the leg on the speed and energy efficiency of the robot is studied. Finally, the explicit finite element (FE) program LS-DYNA simulations are carried out to validate the effectiveness of the model.

sec.title: Description of the impact model for the compliant legged robots
sec.p:
The multi-body system to be analysed, shown in Figure 1, consists of a single-legged robot R and compliant support surface S (fixed). The robot is simplified as a rigid body B and a flexible leg L composed of a thin leaf with a rectangular section and hemispherical end, and they are connected to each other by a hinge J actuated by a servo motor (not shown in Figure 1). The impact is induced by dropping the robot from a certain height. The problem is to predict the general motion of the robot after impact and evaluate the energy loss during the impact. Figure 1.

sec.p: The external forces acting on the robot consist of the weight of R and contact force FS at the contact point T (the terminal point of the leg). More recently, Marghitu et al.17 employed the model for predicting the impact of a rotating link with a massive surface and verified the accuracy of the model by experiment. In this article, the generalized coordinate partitioning technique proposed by Wehage21 was used to solve equation (21). Using this method, the mass matrix M, stiffness matrix K, generalized externally applied forces Qe and quadratic velocity vector Qv can be expressed in terms of qid. Meanwhile, the generalized constraint force vector Cq Tλ will be eliminated. Now, equation (26) can be solved directly by numerical algorithms such as Runge–Kutta, Adams–Bashforth–Moulton or Gear’s methods22 once the boundary conditions are selected correctly.

It should be mentioned that the impact of the compliant legged robot starts at the moment when the end of the leg contacts with the support surface, and ends with the detachment of it from the support surface. Consequently, the numerical integration will be terminated as yT increases from negative to 0 when solving equation (26). The numerical results will be outlined in the following sections together with the simulation results of LS-DYNA.

sec.title: Numerical results and simulations
sec.p: In order to validate the effectiveness of the dynamic model established above for the impact of the compliant legged robots, the explicit FE program ANSYS 12.0/LS-DYNA is utilized. The explicit method of solution used by LS-DYNA provides fast solutions for short-time, large deformation dynamics, quasi-static problems with large deformations and multiple nonlinearities, and complex contact/impact problems.23

sec.title: Description of the LS-DYNA model
sec.p:
The FE model for LS-DYNA simulations is shown in Figure 2. Here, the materials of the body and the support surface are chosen as aluminium and steel, respectively. The leg is constructed of fibreglass with high restitution. The parameters chosen for the theoretical model and simulations are listed in Table 1. Figure 2.

The eight-node brick element SOLID 164 is used to simulate the model. Since the body is supposed to be rigid in the theoretical model presented previously, the number of elements of the body is relatively less than that of the leg as shown in Figure 2. It is worthy to note that the number of the elements nearby the contact area is more than elsewhere. The impact force and friction are modelled by defining the contact parameters such as contact type, static friction coefficient, dynamic friction coefficient, etc. Here, the contact type is set as surface to surface, automatic. The static friction and dynamic friction coefficients are both chosen as 0.48 according to the materials selected for L and S. To save central processing unit time, the analysis starts when the terminal point of the leg is at 0.001 m above S, and an initial velocity of −4.425 m/s is applied to R to simulate the first 0.999 m of free fall (H = 1 m). The solution time is set as 0.0005 s, and the time step is 3.767e−8 s.

Figure 3 represents the variation of the contact deflection during the impact. It is obvious that δ increases from 0 to maximum in the first half phase and declines to zero in the latter half phase. The same is true of the normal impact force and friction (Figure 4). This means that the elastic compression and restitution phases are experienced successively by the compliant leg, and it agrees with the physical phenomena. The calculation and simulation are performed for θ = 45° and g = 9.8 m/s2. Figure 3.

More simulations are performed by changing the incident angle θ, the Young’s modulus E1 and the cross-section parameters of the leg (wL and tL) to study the influence of these parameters on the vertical velocity of the robot after impact. Figure 5 shows that the relative error of vR is not more than 3.87% by comparing the results of analytical model with the LS-DYNA simulations, and this indicates the validity of the dynamic model. Figure 5.
The influences of the variation of the leg’s parameters on the post-impact vertical velocity of the robot: (a) incident angle; (b) Young’s modulus; (c) width; and (d) thickness.

It is clear from Figure 5(a) that the vertical velocity after impact declines with the increasing incident angle, especially when θ is relatively small. Furthermore, as shown in Figure 5(c) and (d), vR increases approximately linearly with wL and tL, while the variation of the Young’s modulus has little effect on vR, as shown in Figure 5(b).

As illustrated in Figure 5, the post-impact vertical velocity is always negative in the cases that were investigated, and consequently, multiple impacts will happen for the robot, which will cause more energy to be lost.

Figure 5(b) to (d) shows that the results of LS-DYNA model oscillate more or less with respect to the numerical results of the theoretical model; these differences may be removed by smaller time step or more number of elements. In addition, the vibrational mode chosen for the theoretical model may also affect the accuracy of the results. It is worthy to note that in the theoretical model, the first vibrational mode (n = 1) is chosen to characterize the elastic deformation of the leg.

As shown in Figure 6(a) and (b), the relative error of the energy loss ratio between the theoretical model and simulations is less than 1.77%, and the rationality of the impact model is validated from the energy point of view. It can also be concluded from Figure 6(b) that the variations of the Young’s modulus have little effect on the energy loss ratio of the robot. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new analytical dynamic model for the impact of the compliant legged robots that consists of interconnected rigid and deformable bodies is proposed. Compared with the SLIP model, this approach provides a means to take into account the factors such as the sliding of the terminal, the vibrations of the leg with distributed compliance and variation of the nonlinear contact force. The effectiveness of the model is validated by the FE program LS-DYNA from the velocity and energy point of view. Accordingly, the model can be used for the dynamic characteristics analysis of robots with more complex compliant leg mechanisms.

All the parameters investigated are more intuitive than the stiffness described in the SLIP model, and these parameters can be used by the designers directly. In the development process of a robot, the width, thickness, materials and the geometric structures of the compliant legs should be optimized to obtain anticipant running or hopping speed. Furthermore, the locomotion of the robots can be controlled by regulating the incident angle of the leg before touching the ground.

In addition, the proposed modelling method can be applied for predicting the post-impact behaviour of the compliant legged robots. In this sense, the vibrations of the compliant legs can be reduced, and the multiple impacts of the robots can be avoided to save energy by choosing proper parameters for the legs during the processes of design and locomotion control.
